start.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

end.title: Raumlichtkunst
end.credit_line:
Oskar Fischinger

Three-screen installation

Reconstruction by Center for Visual Music, USA
end.brief_description: Oskar Fischinger’s Raumlichtkunst is one of the first multimedia projections ever made. Using film projectors, colour filters and slides, Fischinger staged multi-screen film events that were first shown in Germany around 1926 and reconstructed by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles.

links.description: Light Music is considered expanded cinema, which featured multi-screen projections and immersive environments that enveloped the senses. Though coined in the mid 1960s, German artist Oskar Fischinger staged one of the first multi-screen expanded cinema performances with Raumlichtkunst in 1926.

links.description: Light Music is a composition of drawings that Rhodes printed onto the optical edge of a filmstrip that are read as audio by a projector. Similarly, Len Lye also used filmstock in creative ways, painting directly onto celluloid to create A Colour Box

end.title: Fantasia [DVD]
end.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
end.brief_description: An animated feast of music and visuals. Featuring a soundtrack of classical music, including selections by Bach, Tchaikovsky and Moussorgsky, the film weds animated narratives to the famous musical pieces. “Fantasia” includes one of Disney’s most loved sequences, “The Sorcerer’s Apprentice”. At its best the film’s animation remains magical and visually breath-taking.

links.description: In Raumlichtkunst, Fischinger used accompaniments of avant-garde music with his colourful animation. When he emigrated to the United States, he did some preliminary work on Disney’s Fantasia, which featured classical music paired with animation. However, Fischinger’s sequence didn’t appear in the final version.

end.title: Polka-dotting Royal Exhibition Building
end.brief_description: Hugh McSpeeden is a Melbourne-based lighting and projection artist who has been involved with lighting for new music, dance, artists and festivals since 1968. His early 1980s projection of the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne were revolutionary and a precursor to outdoor festival projections.

constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

links.description: Like many expanded cinema artists, Australian Hugh McSpedden staged his colourful, projected works not in cinemas, but in the open air and warehouses. In early 1980s, his polka-dotted projection on the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne was the first-large scale illumination of a public building in Australia.

end.title: Peaky Blinders
end.creator_credit: BBC Studios, Caryn Mandabach Productions, Screen Yorkshire and Tiger Aspect Productions
end.brief_description: A gangster family epic set in 1919 Birmingham, England and centered on a gang who sew razor blades in the peaks of their caps, and their fierce boss Tommy Shelby, who means to move up in the world.

links.description: Lis Rhodes was motivated to make Light Music by the lack of attention given to women composers in European music. Thankfully, since 1975, women composers have gained more prominence. One is Anna Calvi, who recently scored the final seasons of Peaky Blinders.
